thread.title: Prime Minister defends huge cuts to Met Police budget
thread.title_full: Prime Minister defends huge cuts to Met Police budget | London - ITV News

author: Simon Harris
title: Prime Minister defends huge cuts to Met Police budget
text:
The Prime Minister today defended huge cuts to Scotland Yard's budget saying the Met had proved it could 'do more with less'.
David Cameron told ITV News he believed the force could achieve futher savings without axing more than 1,000 community support officers.
And he declined to criticise Boris Johnson for spending more than £200,000 on three water cannon which the government refuses to licence.
The Metropolitan Police Service expects to be told later this year to cut its budget by another £800m.
Senior officers are considering a drastic cost cutting plan which could see all of London's PCSOs axed.
The Met in London have done an excellent job in reducing crime and they've demonstrated over the last five years that you can do more with less. That there are efficiencies you can find. You can get more officers on the front line, you can cut crime and you can save money and we're asking them to continue to do that job.
How exactly the money is saved and indeed the money is spent will be a matter for them. I think community support officers do an excellent job.
– Prime Minister David Cameron London's mayor spent almost £220,000 buying and upgrading three second-hand German water cannons following the riots in 2011 but in July the Home Secretary rejected the Met's request for a licence to use them.
I support what the mayor does and he does an excellent job but here there is a very important role which is for the Home Secretary to decide whether this should be licensed and on the basis. On the basis of the advice she received the evidence to date, the decision was not to do so. But that wasn't ruling it out for ever and a day.
– Prime Minister David Cameron Last updated Mon 5 Oct 2015 Politics
